awd_titl_txt: START Lipid/Sterol Binding Domains in Homeodomain Transcription Factors from Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
In all multicellular organisms, key regulatory proteins orchestrate the developmental program that defines how specific cell types and tissues are formed.  This project will investigate how the regulatory proteins themselves are controlled by interactions with fat molecules. Plants produce a multitude of different fat molecules and other natural products whose molecular functions are not yet understood. The regulatory proteins and fats to be studied in this project are suspected to participate in plant growth control, along with traits that contribute to drought tolerance. Broader impacts of this research will include training of a postdoctoral scholar and several undergraduate students through programs for McNair Scholars, Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation, and the REU program on Ecology and Evolution in Changing Environments. Public outreach will be accomplished through an educational workshop for teenage girls with interests in STEM careers. The information gained from this research will foster discovery of renewable and sustainable plant-derived products. 

Interactions between lipid metabolites and proteins are dynamic in all life forms, yet the full extent and biological significance of these interactions is underexplored. Steroidogenic Acute Regulatory (StAR) protein-related lipid Transfer (START) domains belong to an ancient clan of protein motifs characterized by binding to hydrophobic ligands. In plants, START domains occur in homeodomain leucine-zipper (HD-Zip) transcription factors that are master regulators of cell-type differentiation during development. This project addresses the hypothesis that the START domain controls transcription factor activity via ligand binding to a lipid metabolite, linking cell metabolism to gene expression. The overall goal is to identify the natural ligands of HD-Zip-derived START domains. This research will utilize the Arabidopsis model system focusing on class IV HD-Zip transcription factors that are critical for differentiation of the epidermis. Candidate ligands will be identified by protein-metabolite immunoisolation from plant tissues followed by mass spectrometry. Biochemical approaches will be utilized to validate and further characterize protein-metabolite interactions. This project is poised to uncover novel mechanistic insights in understanding the dynamic interplay between metabolic pathways and the regulation of gene expression in the eukaryotes.

This project is funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

por.por_cntn:
In plants and other multicellular organisms, key proteins regulate gene expression, guiding the developmental program that defines how specific cell types and tissues are formed. Some of these important regulatory proteins are themselves controlled through physical interactions with small molecules, such a lipids. This project focused on a family of developmental regulators that are evolutionarily conserved drivers of growth and cell differentiation in plants. Family members contain a lipid sensor that was previously shown to be required for function of the regulatory protein in the nucleus.

The goal of this project was to study the mechanistic link between lipid metabolism and gene expression using the plant model Arabidopsis. Both in vivo and in vitro approaches were used to identify specific phosphorus-containing lipids as binding partners, indicating a possible link to phosphate homeostasis. Genetic and biochemical studies revealed that the lipid-binding domain is critical for protein dimerization and for protein stability, depending on phosphate availability. The results showed that the lipid-binding activity of the regulatory protein is dispensable for its nuclear localization and DNA binding. In further defining the regulatory protein, it was found that a classical nuclear localization sequence, which partially overlaps with the DNA-binding domain, is critical for its subcellular localization. Moreover, this sequence is required for import to the nucleus by another protein through direct physical interaction. Additional work was performed to characterize the part of the regulatory protein that engages with the molecular machinery involved in up- or down-regulation of gene expression. Our results led to a new mechanistic model in which the lipid-binding regulatory proteins drive gene expression networks through phospholipid metabolism inputs.

This project led to advances in our basic knowledge of the functions of lipid-binding domains and how they modulate plant growth and cell-type differentiation, facilitating technological innovation in the life sciences. Biological resources from this project were made available in public repositories. Postdoctoral research associates and the principal investigator led educational workshops for a summer program that supports teenage girls in pursuit of STEM careers. The research from this study was featured in a podcast on how basic research can help improve the food we eat. Through international collaborations, this project had broader impacts in training next generation researchers with a global science perspective. This project served in training two postdoctoral associates, five graduate students, and twenty undergraduate students including those from underrepresented groups in STEM. Publications from this award included ten research articles, an article in a STEM education journal and one review article. The plant science education-related article was recommended in an academic forum, and two of the research articles were highlighted in scientific journal commentaries.
